value: Most of the carved standing stones are between 1 and 2 meters tall

, known for the remarkable prehistoric burial complex (or at least, that's what researches makes of the site so far) on the outskirts of the village. Almost like a small, African version of Stonehenge, some 36 standing stones, most covered with engravings, are a wonderful archaeological reminder of an early Ethiopian culture. Note that much of the exact background and history of the stones is not yet understood by experts and interpretations of the depicted images vary. Guides will have interesting stories to tell, some of which are backed by research, while other rather stem from local beliefs.

It's possible and convenient to hire a car (with guide) in Addis Ababa. Less convenient but obviously cheaper, you can take public transport. There's an early morning bus to Butajira from Addis Mercato (the market square in Addis Ababa). It leaves before 9am, so make sure you're here early. Ask to be dropped off at Tiya.
The archeological site is located half a kilometre or so from the village centre. If you're here by public transport, you'll be fine walking.
There are a few cheap hotels in town.
